ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of background knowledge on the Middle East, different aspects of Middle Eastern society, and how to analyze literature and write an essay.

I gained a great introduction to Middle Eastern literature from the late 1800s to the modern day, but I also gained skills in analytical writing, comparative analysis, and research as well as a better idea of Middle Eastern culture and history during the time period above.
This class assisted with my reading and literary analysis skills. The platform centered on the Middle East made this class a lot easier to learn the writing and literary skills.

Exposure to a world of literature that I had never had such an immersive experience with, an extremely rewarding class with impactful reads and a new way of approaching global literature and culture in comparison to each other.
Close reading of middle eastern works, placing the texts in a historical context.
This class really helped with my close reading skills and my writing skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: super interesting reading, the essays are honestly pretty fun. Also, Sam is incredible. Go to his office hours any time you have a question, he's super helpful, especially if you are like me when I started the class and don't know a thing about literary analysis. Trust me, I went to him once and asked "how do you analyze" and I got the best explanation of my life.
Weaknesses: some of the reading confused me at times and were never really clarified for me.
Strengths were the class size and discussion format as well as the running if the session by the professor.
incredibly strong instruction, really impactful conversations, i cant wait to see how a class like this thrives in an in-person setting!
I thought this was a super strong course -- really interesting readings, reasonable workload and really good professor.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course worked very smoothly on Zoom just because it was such a small class and mostly based in discussion. Beyond the natural downfalls of not being able to communicate face-to-face, it felt the most normal of all my classes.
all sorts of practices used to adjust to virtual learning were incredibly useful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Take it just for the professor, take it for some super interesting readings, take it to challenge stuff you thought you knew already, take it because it's a non-Eurocentric literature class.
Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone because it helps you hone skills in analysis and writing that are useful in several contexts and the subject matter is very interesting.
I would. The professor was very strong and accessible. In addition it was a solid way to gain reading and writing skills.

of course - i think more students could benefit from a writing/humanities course outside of whats typically taught in classes that focus on the western canon. and a perfect class for anyone who is interested in specifically this area of literature
If you want to learn more about middle eastern literature, go for it. You will have to do a lot of reading (and occasional writing).
I would definitely recommend this course

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
